ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained knowledge about Yale's history and the different aspects that shape a college education today. Learning more about the financial side of college was interesting and discussing post graduation outlooks.
I developed a critical insight on how the American higher education system is supposed to work.

The course was an overview of some of the components of a college education and how they affect our lives as college students. But I, like most students, enrolled in the course as an international student to satisfy a visa requirement, so I didn't really learn much lol.
honestly nothing
I obtained a general understanding of college education.
I learned more about Yale and its history as an institution.
Insight into different aspects of college administration and philosophy
College education matters.
A better understanding of why we are at college, and how to better frame our experience.
Gained important context and concepts about college

This course provided an introduction to the history of Yale, the philosophy of education, and the landscape of higher education more broadly. We read some engaging texts related to curriculums, class, and privilege. My favorite part of the course came at the end when we explored memoirs from Coates, Westover, and others. I enjoyed thinking critically about the education we are receiving at Yale, especially with the large cohort of international students in the class.
Got to learn a lot about the college process and applying to college. Great course!
Our section discussions allowed me to develop reading comprehension skills. We would critically discuss every reading we had.
I loved this class! Great readings, wonderful Professor and TAs. Delightful.
I think the way discussion sections complemented the weekly lectures really helped us understand many aspects of the contents of college education as a progression throughout history and cultures.
A more nuanced perspective to view Yale and the role of college education.

Thanks to this course, I was introduced to some insightful ideas and experiences surrounding college education. Indeed, this course encouraged me to look at college from different angles, including memoirs, administrative statements, historical records, etc.

An interesting look at the experiences and thoughts of various thinkers, all loosely centered around the theme of college education. You get to examine college from economic, social or philosophical perpsectives.
i understood more about yale as a university and how i should make the most out of this university experience
In this course, I started to think a bit more critically about my time at Yale so far and how I want to use the time I have left. I also learned about the travails of meritocracy.
Writing, reading, and critical thinking skills.
Opening of mind to new ideas

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was hard to engage with due to the remote aspect. It's often hard to engage remotely with a recoded lecture. The in-person element would have been more enjoyable, so I recommend that for people able to attend on campus.

Strengths: Pretty much no work, and being pass/fail, the work itself required zero effort. Content-wise, every lecture had an interesting insight or two, and it's a fun half-credit to take if you need it. Also, Prof Lewis is a great guy, and his soliloquys and discussions have restored a tiny fragment of my faith in the Yale administration. Weaknesses: The content does get a bit drab at times, especially if you don't particularly enjoy history and/or literature.
the readings were interesting but lectures and section were useless and felt like Yale propaganda. Marvin Chun's guest lecture was an hour-long speech justifying Yale's obsession with the endowment

The course is well-organized into distinct parts and helps understand what college is about. However, the insights drawn from this course don't go further than the common knowledge about college education. I also appreciated guest speakers at this class.
The material itself is engaging, but it was difficult to really engage and follow along when the lecture was recorded live.
Solid course.
Very engaging lecture and course material.
Slightly unstructured at times but very cool discussion modes

Professor Lewis is an extremely kind, caring, and intelligent man who makes it clear how deeply he cares for our well-being. The class provided a low stress environment to have conversations I believe all students should have. It is important to think critically about the role of college in our lives as we step through these formative years.
Can't think of any weaknesses. Was a really good course
A weakness of the sections is that it is strictly analyzing our reading assignments. There was not much discussion about lectures or topics of the essays we've had.
I loved this class! Great readings, wonderful Professor and TAs. Delightful.
I think having small discussion sections for such a large lecture helped us understand and discuss concepts beyond what we could go during the lecture were very helpful.
The main strength of the course is the professor's and the teaching fellows' level of engagement with the given material. They always encourage us to analyze them from different perspectives.

Prof Lewis was great and always enthusiastic. He managed to foster balanced discussions about relatively touchy topics. Was a great, relaxed course to fulfill the in-person requirement for international students.
Pretty interesting topics e.g. cost of Yale, history of liberal arts education

strengths: very engaging topics
weaknesses: too much reading workload

Professor Lewis was the main strength of this course. He made the class (which, for future readers, was mainly composed of first-year international students who needed to take an in-person class for visa purposes) into a true community, and I am grateful to him for that. His thoughtfulness and intentionality regarding the course material were apparent. Regarding possible improvements: I am not sure if this course will be taught in the future, but if so, I do not think sections are necessary.
This course was extremely well-organized and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The section I was in was led by a really great TF. Section was by far the best part of this course. It was a very comfortable atmosphere where we shared our experiences in college so far. I highly recommend section!
Lectures were in-person, which allowed for much more engaging teaching. However, keeping sections virtual nevertheless succeeded because of their small size.
Well-adapted
Really enjoyed the in-person component, Professor Lewis did a great job!
Like the in person components.
Recording lectures was nice for students who were anxious about going in person
It was helpful that the lectures were recorded. The use of guest speakers enhanced the effectiveness of lectures.
Everything was organized in a great way.
Lectures were also recorded, which was helpful.

The courses lecture was taught in-person, which I loved, and the courses sections were virtual. I always attended the lecture, which was filmed live, in-person, so I cannot speak on its virtual component.
This course was very well-organized during the pandemic. Despite being an online course, the recordings were also always uploaded promptly. The assignments were uploaded well ahead of time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, for section (hopefully you get a great TF like we had). The lectures were okay, but section was really nice to discuss with peers about each others college experience so far.

Most students took this course either for the free pass/fail half-credit, or for a visa requirement during a COVID semester. If this course is ever offered again, unless you really enjoy perusing literature and/or history related to a college education, the only reason you might take it is for the free half-credit (or maybe to get to know Prof Lewis, who is a wonderful guy).
If you need a half-credit and don't want a lab, take this because it's mindless but otherwise don't bother
yes if you don't want to have a lot of work
Definitely, if youre at risk of getting deported

I would recommend this course if you want to learn more about Yale as an institution. But I would only recommend taking this course if you have a lighter workload. Of course, the workload isn't a lot, but if you really want to learn, you'll be more motivated if you're not worrying about other courses.
A truly exceptional class. Thoughtful and interesting discussions yet very little stress associated with the class. What a college course should be
yes! professor Lewis is very engaging and I had great discussions in the sections.
If they want a pass/fail class.
Yes; interesting course material, taught by a strong teacher.

This class is a refreshing break from other coursework. It is half a credit, so the workload is very limited. If they offer this class again and you are an underclass man looking to think carefully about Yale and your place within this institution, I would consider taking it!
Yes! Very interesting material.
Yes, it is interesting to know more about the system of education we are in and why colleges make certain decisions.
Absolutely!
I would recommend this course if you want to discuss aspects of college education with people from various backgrounds.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the basis of college education as a concept that can be approached in multiple different ways. I would especially recommend this course to anyone who is interested in studying how college education can be reflected in class, politics, etc.
Absolutely- makes you think about really interesting topics and orients yourself at Yale
definately!

I am not sure if this years iteration of the course will be taught again, but I would recommend it to another studentthe material is generally interesting. One caveat is that the courses pass/fail nature may make it difficult for some to stay consistently engaged.
Yes! I think that the topics covered in this course covered a broad range of topics that are all extremely interesting. The sections and the in-person lectures are both very enjoyable.
Provided very interesting incite on the purpose of the college education as well as the benefits it holds after college life
Yes

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lectures were recorded with the option to attend in person if you were on campus. Sections were live zoom sessions in seminar format.
Lectures recorded, virtual sections

virtual sections,
streamed lecture
Recorded in-person lecture + virtual discussion section
In person + live + recorded
discussion section
Virtual discussion section
Discussion section.
Could also attend lecture virtually.
Readings
I alternated between attending in person lecture and attending remotely.
In person, but I did it online (lectures were recorded)
Lecture and weekly section
In person lecture accompanied with virtual discussion sections.
discussion section
discussion sections were done on zoom
We also had a virtual section
Discussion sections were live virtual.
Recorded lecture present
